defs.etymology: See az.

words: az, for words starting with a vowel sound

examples: a hölgy ― the lady
a héten ―  this week

text: (in reduplicated constructions formed with postpositions) that
examples: A mellett a ház mellett vártam rá. ― I waited for him/her next to that house.

text: (rare, only in consonant-initial fixed phrases, with zero article) Alternative form of az (“that”).
examples: Foglalja össze, miről szóltak az a heti beszédek és leckék. ― Summarize what that week’s sermons and lessons were about.
November 12-én, az a havi frissítőkedden jelenhet meg. ― It may be released on November 12th, on the Patch Tuesday of that month.
Kérjük szíves tájékoztatásukat a tekintetben, hogy…  ― We kindly request your information in that [= the] aspect…
amondó vagyok, hogy… ― I am of the opinion that…, what/all I can / want to say is that…

text: (identifier or musical note): IPA: [ˈaː] (in the names of minor scales; see also A)
The first letter of the Hungarian alphabet, written in the Latin script.
(music) designation of the sixth note from C and the corresponding tone
(identifier or musical note): IPA: [ˈaː] (in the names of minor scales; see also A)

defs.etymology: From Proto-Finno-Ugric *ne (“no, not”). In Ugric languages, e.g. in Mansi language, it has been used only in pronominal forms such as nē-mat (nothing), nē-m-at-χōt (nowhere), Mansi нэ̄мхуньт (nè̄mhunʹt, “never”).

examples:
…másképp szólva, mi ketten együtt vagyunk a kozmosz kettes számrendszerének igenje és nemje, belénk írva a program, mely a világot mozgatja.
…in other words, we both are together the yes and no of the binary system of the cosmos, with the program that moves the world written in us.
…in other words, we both are together the yes and no of the binary system of the cosmos, with the program that moves the world written in us.
nemet mond ― to say no

defs.etymology: Of unknown origin.

text: gender. Usually, társadalmi nem to distinguish sex and gender.
(biology, taxonomy) genus (rank in a taxonomic classification between family and species)
examples: egyedülálló a maga nemében ― unique of its kind

defs.etymology: The pronoun and determiner senses probably derive from an earlier a + a pronoun-forming suffix -z, where the former element originates from Proto-Uralic *o or *u (“that, that other”). Its cognates include Moksha омба (omba, “other”), омбоце (omboce, “second”), Eastern Mari умбал (umbal, “far, distant”), Udmurt отын (otyn, “there”) and Komi-Zyrian [script needed] (ata, “here”), [script needed] (asi̮, “look here”).The definite article was created by means of conversion, originally only in the form az, later shortened to a’ before consonants until the early 20th century, when the spelling a was accepted.

text: the (for words beginning with a vowel) [from 13th–14th c.]
examples: az iskola ― the school
Coordinate terms: ez, emez, amaz
Az ott egy ház. ― That is a house over there.
Az tetszik nekem a legjobban. ― That is what I like the most.

text: (used before a noun phrase with a definite article, declined in accordance with the noun phrase it applies to) that
(rare, archaic, except in vowel-initial fixed phrases, with zero article) that
examples: Coordinate terms: ez, emez, amaz
Az a ház nagyon szép. ― That house is very beautiful.
Azzal a dobozzal nem tudok mit kezdeni. ― I cannot do anything with that box.
Azokban a házakban venezuelaiak laknak. ― In those houses, Venezuelan people are living.
Synonym:  a
Coordinate terms: e, ez, eme, emez, ama, amaz, ezen, azon
az ügyben  ― in that matter
az évben  ― in that year
az az évi díjak  ― the fees of that year

defs.etymology: From Proto-Uralic *kuńćɜ, from *ku (“interrogative stem”). Cognates include Komi-Zyrian кыдз (kydz, “how”), Eastern Mari кузе (kuze, “how”), perhaps Finnish konsa (“when”).

examples: Synonyms: hogyan,  miként, miképp, miképpen
Hogy vagy? ― How are you?
Hogy érzi magát? ― How are you feeling?

text: (followed by indicative mood, used with -e or a question word, often omitted) if, whether (or not translated)
(followed by subjunctive/imperative mood, occasionally omitted) to (expressing imperative in reported speech)
(followed by subjunctive/imperative mood, optionally preceded by azért, abból a célból or avégett) so, so that, so as to, in order to, in order that (specifying the aim or goal of an action)
examples: Látom, hogy itt vagy. ― I see that you are here.
Láttam, hogy jössz. ― I saw you coming.
Nem tudom,  akar-e jönni. ― I don't know if s/he wants to come.
Nem tudom,  mikor akar jönni. ― I don't know when s/he wants to come.
Mondtam neki, hogy maradjon otthon. ― I told him/her to stay at home.
Átmegyek a másik szobába, hogy ne zavarjalak. ― I'll go to the other room so I don't disturb you.
Azért megyek át a másik szobába, hogy ne zavarjalak. ― I'll go to the other room so that I don't disturb you.

defs.etymology:
From e (“this”).
Doublet of is (“too, even, again”).

examples: Synonyms: s, meg, illetve, valamint
Coordinate terms: a,  az
egy csepp a tengerben ― a drop in the ocean
Synonyms: azonos, ugyanaz, egyező, megegyező

text: (folksy, before numerals) some, or so, roughly, around, approximately

defs.etymology:
From Old Hungarian vagyon. See Hungarian volt.
Forms beginning with v- are from Proto-Finno-Ugric *wole- (“to be”). Cognate with Mansi о̄луӈкве (ōluňkve), Finnish olla and Estonian olema. Compare inflected forms such as volt, volna, való and Old Hungarian vola or vala. The root in present tense (vagy-) is result of palatization: /vɒl/ > /vɒʎ/ > /vɒj/ > /vɒɟ/.
Forms beginning with l- are from Proto-Finno-Ugric *le- (“to become”). Cognate with Finnish lienee (potential of olla), Karelian lienöy (potential of olla), Northern Sami leat.

text: to be (auxiliary verb indicating a type of passive voice along with the adverbial participle form of the main verb)
examples: Synonym: létezik
Antonym: nincs
Péternek van egy kutyája. ― Peter has a dog.
Van itt valaki? ― Is there anybody here?
A probléma még nincs megoldva. ― The question isn’t yet solved.
„Szakmány módra van rám mérve minden óra: / Jöttem kegyelmedhez búcsuvevő szóra.”“Every hour is measured as though by contract. / I come to bid you now farewell.”
“Every hour is measured as though by contract. / I come to bid you now farewell.”

defs.etymology: From Proto-Uralic *e- (“this”). Cognates include Finnish että and Estonian et.

text: this, it (used as a pronoun, that is, instead of a noun phrase)
examples: Coordinate term: az
Ez egy szép ház. ― This is a nice house.
Ez nem jó. ― This is not good.
Ez vagyok én. ― This is me.
Ez a kutyám. ― This is my dog.
Ez kedves tőled. ― It is nice of you.

text: (used before a noun phrase with a definite article, gets the case of the noun phrase) this
(archaic, otherwise only in certain fixed phrases beginning with a vowel, as a counterpart of e, followed by no article) this
examples: Ez a ház nagyon szép. ― This house is very beautiful.
Ezzel a lemezzel nem tudok mit kezdeni. ― I cannot do anything with this disk.
ez ügyben  ― in this matter
ez esetben  ― in this case
ez évben  ― in this year
az ez évi díjak ― [“the”] this year's fees
ez alkalommal ― on this occasion
ez idő szerint ― at this time, at present, presently
ez idő tájt ― about this time, in these days

defs.etymology: Doublet of és (“and”).

text: even, up to, as much as, as long as
(after an interrogative word) again (used in a question to ask something one has forgotten)
examples: Synonyms: szintén, ugyancsak, úgyszintén, éppúgy,  szintúgy
Én is szeretem a csokit. ― I, too, like chocolate .
a csokit is szeretem. ― I also like chocolate .
Három óráig is tarthat a műtét ― The operation may even take three hours.
Hogy is hívják? ― What's that called, again?

defs.etymology: For the adverbial use, compare Polish ale.

examples: De szép ez a ház! ― Oh, how beautiful that house is!
Synonyms:  be, milyen, mennyire

text: (oh) yes!, surely! (used as a positive contradiction to a negative statement)
examples: Synonyms: viszont, azonban, ám, ugyanakkor, ellenben
Synonym: de igen
Nem voltál itt! – De ott voltam. ― You weren’t here! – Yes I was!

defs.etymology: From Proto-Finno-Ugric *müŋä (“rear, beyond”). For a similar semantic development, see Finnish cognate myös (“also, too”). Of the same origin as mögött, mögé, and mögül.

text: plus (sum of the previous one and the following one)
examples: Synonyms: és, s
Csak te meg én! ― Only you and me!
Három meg egy egyenlő néggyel. ― Three plus one equals four.

defs.etymology: Of unknown origin.

text: just, only, merely, solely (when something is not as great or as much or as serious as could be expected)
for a reason that the speaker does not want to specify
it's just that, but (explaining a reason that restricts or prevents the effectiveness of the event specified previously)
(the emphasis being on the subsequent verb) if only, I wish (in wishes); indicates less hope if used with conditional mood, more certainty if used with subjunctive)
(with emphasis) supposedly, must, after all (describing supposition, based on how things normally turn out)
(with emphasis) nevertheless, nonetheless, all the same (expressing resistance or defiance)
used in imperative sentences to indicate something quick or immediate
don't bother, do as you wish (in imperative sentences)
as late as, no sooner (than…), not until (that…)
(after relative pronouns like aki, ami, ahol etc.) -ever, no matter (whoever, whatever, wherever etc. or no matter who/what/where etc.)
examples: Csak a sajtos pizzát szeretem. ― I only like cheese pizza.
Synonyms: csupán, csakis, kizárólag, egyedül
Ez csak játék. ― This is just a game.
Synonyms: csupán, pusztán, mindössze
Ezt miért csináltad? - Csak! ― Why did you do that? - Just because!
Synonym: csak úgy
Hívtalak telefonon! – Hallottam, csak épp zuhanyoztam. ― I called you on the phone! – I heard, but I was in the shower.
Nyerhetett volna a csapat, csak nem volt elég jó az edzőjük. ― The team could have won, it's just that their coach wasn't good enough.
Ő is ott volt, csak a másik szobában. ― He was also there, but in the other room.
Csak élné/élje túl a balesetet! ― If only he survived the accident!
Synonym: bárcsak
Synonyms: biztos, biztosan
Előbb-utóbb csak hazajön! ― Sooner or later, he/she/it must get back home, after all!
Synonyms: mégis,  mégiscsak, mégsem,  mégse
Hiába mondtam neki, ő csak nem akarta megérteni. ― I kept explaining it to him/her in vain; s/he just refused to understand it.
Mondtuk neki, hogy nyugodtan maradhat, de ő csak hazament a többiekkel. ― We told him/her s/he was welcome to stay some more while but s/he did go home with the others, nevertheless.
Nézd csak! ― Hey, look!
Várj csak! ― Wait a minute! / Hold on for a second!
Figyelj csak! ― Listen up!
Menj csak! ― Go, don't bother.
Hagyd csak! ― Just let him!
Dohányozz csak! Magadnak ártasz vele, nem nekem! ― Smoke if you wish! You're hurting yourself, not me.
Synonym: felőlem
Elromlott az ébresztőórám, és csak 10-kor ébredtem fel. ― My alarm clock broke down and I didn't wake up until 10 a.m..

A tudomány csak a 16–17. században kezdett megválni a négy fő testnedv elméletétől. ― It wasn't until the 16th and 17th century that science started to discard the theory of the four principal bodily humors.
Synonyms: bár-, akár-
Amit csak kérsz, megadom neked. ― I'll give you whatever you want.
Ahol csak járt, mindenütt barátokat szerzett. ― He made friends wherever he went.
Akkor jössz, amikor csak akarsz. ― You can come whenever you like.

defs.etymology: Lexicalization of the h- stem of hogy +‎ -á (lative case suffix). The original form was probably há, where the ending later shortened to -a.

text: if (introducing a conditional clause; often coupled with akkor (“then”))
examples: Ha meglátod a parkot, fordulj jobbra. ― When you see the park, turn right.

defs.etymology: Onomatopoeic.

text: (regional) drawing attention to some soft sound
examples:
Ha, ha! Mi zúg? … mi éji dal / London utcáin ez?
[untranslated] what is the din / In London's streets so late?
[untranslated] what is the din / In London's streets so late?

defs.etymology: From Proto-Uralic *me.
From Proto-Uralic *mi.

text: (after van or nincs in any tense and mood, followed by an infinitive) something, anything, nothing
examples: Mi van a kezedben? ― What is in your hand?
Nincs mit hozzátennem. ― I have nothing to add.
Még szerencse, hogy volt mit enni! ― It's lucky there was something to eat!
Örülnék, ha lenne mit nézni a tévében. ― I would be glad if there were something to watch on TV.
Van mire tenni a vázát? ― Is there anything to put the vase on?

text: (now only in certain set phrases) what?
examples: Synonyms: milyen, miféle
mi okból? ― for what reason?
mi célból? ― for what purpose/goal?
mi végből/végre? ― to what end?
mi módon? ― in what manner?
mi fán terem? ― what kind of thing is it?
Mi gyönyörűség! ― What beauty!
Synonyms:  mily,  milyen,  micsoda,  minő

defs.etymology: (This etymology is missing or incomplete. Please add to it, or discuss it at the Etymology scriptorium.)

text: mi (a syllable used in solfège to represent the third note of a major scale)
examples: Coordinate terms: dó, ré, fá, szó, lá, ti

defs.etymology:
From Old Hungarian ɛ̄n. Usually considered to continue the Proto-Uralic first-person pronoun *minä (compare e.g. Finnish minä), but there is no consensus on how the Hungarian word has developed to its present shape. At least four proposals have been advanced:irregular loss of the word-initial *m-
from earlier *ɛmen, through the vocalization and loss of word-internal *-m-, as in many other cases such as ó (“old”)
from earlier *ɛ̄mn, with the cluster *mn simplified to n
from earlier *ɛ̄m, derived from the shorter Uralic root *mi, and with the irregular simplification of the root-final *-m to -n, perhaps first in the accusative engem (< ? *ɛmgɛm).
The last three options assume that the word was prefixed with *ɛ- at some point, perhaps an intensifying particle, or from the Proto-Uralic pronoun root *e- (“this”) (compare ez (“this”)).
Similarly irregular first-person pronouns occur in Mansi: ам (am) (Northern), [script needed] (äm) (Southern), and even in Chuvash: эпӗ (ep̬ĕ) from Proto-Turkic *ben. If these have a similar origin as the Hungarian word, they are the most compatible with the third and fourth explanations.

examples: Én vagyok a képen. ― I am in the picture.

defs.etymology: az (“that”) +‎ -t (accusative suffix)

examples: Vedd le azt a dobozt a polcról. ― Take that box off the shelf.
Azt mondta, hogy pontosan érkezik. ― He said he will arrive on time.

defs.etymology: From the same Proto-Finno-Ugric *wole- or *woli- as Finnish and Estonian olla. Compare similarities with Old Hungarian vola, later vala (same meaning).

text: third-person singular indicative past indefinite of van
examples: Milyen volt az előadás? ― How was the show?
az egyetem volt tanára ― the former professor of the university

defs.etymology: Named after the Italian physicist Alessandro Volta.
Probably a lexicalization of the i- stem variant of the demonstrative pronoun e ~ ez.

examples: Synonym: nagyon

Az történt vele ebben a pillanatban, ami az emberrel történni szokott, ha váratlanul igen szégyenletes dolgon érik. Arcát nem tudta a helyzethez szabni, amelybe bűne felfedésével a felesége előtt került.
There happened to him at that instant what does happen to people when they are unexpectedly caught in something very disgraceful. He did not succeed in adapting his face to the position in which he was placed towards his wife by the discovery of his fault.

There happened to him at that instant what does happen to people when they are unexpectedly caught in something very disgraceful. He did not succeed in adapting his face to the position in which he was placed towards his wife by the discovery of his fault.

Utolsónak mostohaanyám legidősebb bátyja, Lajos bácsi érkezett. Ő valami igen fontos tisztséget tölt be a családunkban, bár egész pontosan meghatározni nem tudnám, milyet.The last person to arrive was my stepmother’s oldest brother, Uncle Lajos. He fulfills some terribly important function in our family, though I’d be hard put to define exactly what that was.
The last person to arrive was my stepmother’s oldest brother, Uncle Lajos. He fulfills some terribly important function in our family, though I’d be hard put to define exactly what that was.
Synonyms:  aha,  ja
Antonym: nem

defs.etymology: From the expression az vagyon (“that is”). Compare Polish bądź.

examples: Ez vagy az? ― This or that?
Vagy itt van, vagy ott. ― It is either here or there.
Synonyms: nagyjából, körülbelül, mintegy
Megevett vagy hat szendvicset. ― He ate about six sandwiches.

defs.etymology: (This etymology is missing or incomplete. Please add to it, or discuss it at the Etymology scriptorium.)

text: second-person singular indicative present indefinite of van
examples: Hol vagy? ― Where are you?

defs.etymology: From Proto-Finno-Ugric *kelke- (“to be necessary, need to, must, be obligatory”).

text: (auxiliary with a verb in the infinitive) must, need to, have to
examples: Synonyms: muszáj, kénytelen
Ezt látnod kell. ― You have to / need to / must see it.
Synonym: szüksége van
Kell nekem az a ház. ― I need that house.

defs.etymology: (This etymology is missing or incomplete. Please add to it, or discuss it at the Etymology scriptorium.)

examples: El a kezekkel! ― Hands off!

defs.etymology: Lexicalization of the earlier i variant of the e demonstrative pronoun + -tt (locative suffix).

examples: Itt születtem. ― I was born here.
Coordinate term:  ott

text: already (prior to some time), yet (in some questions)
(in declarative and interrogative sentences) still, (in negation) yet
(any/some) more (equivalent to több/többet or tovább in negations)
(before a comparative adjective or adverb) even
examples: Synonym:  még mindig
Antonym: már
Még itt vagyok. ― I'm still here.
Még nem vagyok ott. ― I'm not yet there.
Van még kérdés? ― Are there any more questions?
Kérsz még? ― Would you like some more?
Egyél még! ― Eat some more.
Jó, akkor várok még. ― All right, then I'll wait more.
még több ― even more
Ne hallgass rá! ― Don't listen to him!
Ne felejtsd el! or  El ne felejtsd! ―  don't forget it!
Miért ne?  ― Why not?
Bár ne tettem volna! ― I wish I hadn't done it.
Ne lopj! ― Thou shalt not steal.

defs.etymology: From the same Proto-Uralic root *tinä as e.g. Finnish sinä, Mari Eastern Mari тый (tyj) and Komi-Zyrian тэ (te).
From Proto-Ugric.

text: out, not inside, from the inside, in an outward direction

defs.etymology: From Proto-Uralic *ke, the same root from which the Finnish ken and Ter Sami kie are derived.

text: (interrogative) who (what person or people; which person or people)
(relative, archaic) Synonym of aki (“who”, the person or people that)
(relative, archaic) Synonym of az, aki (“who”, whoever, he/she who, they who)
examples:
Gondoljatok arra, kit messze rejtek / rejt tőletek, ki ha kóstolja bortok / nem érzi már ízét sem; és ha szóltok / nem érti, s más összhang mit vágya kerget.
 Think of the one who is hidden from you by a distant hideout, who when tasting your wine will not sense its savor anymore, [who] will not understand when you speak to him, and it’s a different harmony [that] his desire pursues.

Think of the one who is hidden from you by a distant hideout, who when tasting your wine will not sense its savor anymore, [who] will not understand when you speak to him, and it’s a different harmony [that] his desire pursues.

Ki erre, ki arra szaladt. ― Some ran this way; some, the other way.

defs.etymology: mi (“what?”) +‎ -t (accusative suffix)

examples: Mit gondolsz? ― What do you think?
Mit szórakozol velem? ― Why  are you messing with me?

defs.etymology: ez +‎ -t

examples: Vedd le ezt a dobozt a polcról. ― Take this box off the shelf.

defs.etymology: vagy (second-person singular indicative present indefinite of van) +‎ -ok (personal suffix)

text: first-person singular indicative present indefinite of van
examples: én vagyok ― I am
Én vagyok az! ― It's me!

defs.etymology: From the earlier ma (“now”), which in modern Hungarian means “today” + -st. For the suffix, compare valamelyest.
From Proto-Ugric *jomɜ ~ *jamɜ (“good”). Cognates include Mansi ёмас (ëmas, “good, right, nice”).

text: good (good for something (can be used for) -ra/-re, good at something -ban/-ben, good for someone (positively affects) -nak/-nek, good to someone [e.g. helping, caring] -hoz/-hez/-höz)
(used with ideje/ideig, darab, adag, néhány and some other fixed phrases) quite (some), fair (amount of…), considerable, significant, hefty, sizeable
examples: See synonyms at Thesaurus:jó.
Antonym: rossz
Synonyms: jókora, jelentős
Jó ideje vándorolt már. ― He had been on his way for quite some time.

text: B (an academic grade, better than a C and worse than an A) (Uses only the "jó-" stem, not "jav-".)
(plural only) goods, possessions, assets (see at javak)
examples: Még a jóktól is elvették a javaikat.Even the good ones were deprived of their possessions.
Even the good ones were deprived of their possessions.

defs.etymology: From Proto-Uralic *joke. Cognates include Mansi я̄ (â̄, “river”), Finnish joki (“river”), Estonian jõgi (“river”), Karelian jogi (“river”), Veps jogi (“river”). Replaced by folyó.

text: (obsolete) river (occurs in compound proper names, such as Sajó, Berettyó, Héjő)

defs.etymology: tud +‎ -om

text: first-person singular indicative present definite of tud
examples: Tudom, hol van. ― I know where it is.

text: so (in that manner, in such a way)
Evidential marker, approx. “apparently”; see the Usage notes below and the Wikipedia article.
examples: Coordinate term:  így

defs.etymology: mi (“what”) +‎ -ért (“for”, causal-final case ending)

examples: Elmentek tejért. – Miért mentek? – Tejért.“They went for milk.” “For what did they go?” “For milk.”
“They went for milk.” “For what did they go?” “For milk.”

defs.etymology: az (“that”) +‎ -kor (“time, at the time of”)

text: then, as a result, in that case (often coupled with ha (“if”))
examples: akkortól kezdve ― from then on
Coordinate term: ekkor

defs.etymology: Lexicalization of mi (“what?”) +‎ -n (case suffix) +‎ -t (locative suffix).

text: (comparison of things with a quality present at different degrees) than
(comparison of things with a quality present at the same degree) as …… as
(comparison of things with some similar quality) like
(somewhat formal, pointing at a comparable feature at a different instance) as
(stating someone's capacity in a situation) as
examples: A kastély nagyobb, mint a kutyaház. ― The castle is bigger than the dog-house.
Synonyms: -nál/-nél,  -tól/-től
Olyan nagy a házam, mint a tiéd. ― My house is as big as yours.
Synonyms: amint,  akár,  akárcsak
Olyan ez a ház, mint egy kastély. ― This house is like a castle.
Synonyms: amint,  akár,  akárcsak
Mint mondtam, ő nem tud ma eljönni. ― As I said, he cannot come today.
Synonyms: amint, ahogy, ahogyan
János mint zsűritag vett részt az eseményen. ― János took part in the event as a member of the jury.
Synonyms: -ként, -képp/-képpen, -ul/-ül

defs.etymology: From Proto-Finno-Ugric *se (“he, she, it”). Cognates include Southern Mansi tü, tüw-, Northern Mansi тав (tav, “he, she”), Finnish hän.

text: (personal) he, she (third-person singular, nominative form; usually omitted as redundant due to the verb suffix, except for emphasis or contrast)

Optional (redundant) element used for emphasis in third-person possessive constructions, whether singular or plural, if the possessor is otherwise not explicit; normally preceded by the article az (“the”):
examples: Ő hagyta itt. ― S/he left it here [it was left here by him/her, rather than by someone else].
az ő asztala  ― his/her table/desk
az ő széke  ― his/her chair
az ő asztaluk  ― their table/desk
az ő székük  ― his/her chair

text: The twenty-seventh letter of the Hungarian alphabet, called ő and written in the Latin script.

defs.etymology: Lexicalization of jó (“good”) +‎ -l (adverb-of-manner suffix).

examples: A: Hogy vagy? B: Köszönöm, jól. ― A: How are you? B: Fine, thank you.

defs.etymology: From Proto-Finno-Ugric *le- (“to be, exist, live; will be”, compare Proto-Finnic *leedäk) + -sz ([now obsolete] frequentative suffix; see its entry for more).

text: future of van (“to be”): will be
(intransitive, copulative) to become, get, turn into (out of someone or something: -ból/-ből; into something, achieving a state: nominative or [less commonly] -vá/-vé)
(intransitive, copulative) to occur, come to pass, come about, happen, come into being, take place, befall (with -val/-vel)
must be, have to be (expressing probability or logical necessity)
examples: Synonyms: válik, változik, átváltozik, alakul, átalakul, fordul
Az ebihalból béka lesz. ― The tadpole turns into a frog.
Synonym: történik
Mi lett vele, miután elküldték? ― What happened to him after he was dismissed?
Ez a postás lesz. ― It must be the postman.
Synonyms:  biztos, biztosan

text: IPA: [ˈlɛsː], [ˈlɛs] (long before a vowel or at the end of a sentence; short before a consonant)

defs.etymology: nagy (“great”) +‎ -on (“-ly”, adverb-forming suffix)

examples: Synonyms:  rendkívül, igen, módfelett, szerfelett
Antonyms: kicsit,  kissé, kevéssé

defs.etymology: nagy (“great”) +‎ -on (“on”, superessive suffix)
nem (“no, not”) +‎ s (emphatic-enhancing word, same as és and is)

text: there is no, there is not
examples: Antonym: van
nincs mit tenni ― there is nothing to do

defs.etymology: Shortened from meret, an obsolete variant of miért (“why”).

text: because (by or for the cause that; on this account that; for the reason that)
examples: Becsuktam az ablakot, mert fáztam. or Azért csuktam be az ablakot, mert fáztam. ― I closed the window because I was cold.
Synonyms: mivel, ugyanis, minthogy, merthogy, hiszen,  miután
Coordinate term:  azért

defs.etymology: mer (“to dare; to ladle”) +‎ -t (past-tense and past-participle suffix)

text: third-person singular indicative past indefinite of mer

defs.etymology: First attested in the early 13th century. Lexicalization of mind (“all”) +‎ -en (suffix to form adverbs of manner or pronouns).

text: every (used with the noun in singular)
examples: Synonyms: mindegyik, minden egyes

text: construed with sok, több, mi, ennyi, annyi: thing (referring to numerous items together, possibly the totality of the set)
examples: Megvettél mindent, amit akartál? ― Did you buy everything you wanted?
Synonym: dolog
Sok mindent tudnék mesélni. ― I could tell you about a lot of things.

defs.etymology: mind (“all [of them]”) +‎ -en (“on”, superessive suffix)

examples: Sok jó viccet mondott, szinte minden nevettünk. ― S/he told a lot of good jokes; we laughed at almost all of them.

defs.etymology: mind (“all [of them]”) +‎ -en (adverb-forming suffix)

examples: Julit sem láttam. ― I didn’t see Juli, either. [aside from not having seen another person]
Én sem láttam Julit. ― I didn’t see Juli, either. [aside from other people who haven't seen her]
Meg sem próbálta. ― S/he didn’t even try it.
Sem te, sem ő nem jöhettek velem. ― Neither you nor s/he can come with me.

defs.etymology: ami +‎ -t

examples: Betartom, amit ígértem. ― I keep what I promised.

defs.etymology: oly +‎ -an

examples: Olyan embert keres, aki tud jól gépelni. ― He is looking for such a person who can type well.

text: such a thing, something like that, that kind of thing
examples: Az egyik olyan, mint a másik. ― One is like the other.
Coordinate term: ilyen

defs.etymology: rend +‎ -ben

text: (with van (“to be”), optionally omitted in the 3rd-person singular present indicative) all right, okay
examples: Minden rendben ? ― Is everything okay?

defs.etymology: From i, original form of e (“this”).

text: (demonstrative) in this way, like this (replaces an adverb)
examples: Synonyms: ily módon, ekképp, ekképpen
Coordinate term: úgy

text: thus, as a result, hence, therefore, consequently (between a phrase and a conclusion of it)
examples: Synonyms: ezért,  ennélfogva,  úgyhogy

text: in (towards the interior of a defined space, such as a building or room)
examples: Antonym: ki

defs.etymology: From the vol- stem of van +‎ -na.

text: third-person singular conditional present of van
examples: Synonym: lenne
jó volna ― it would be good

defs.etymology: From American English okay.

examples: Synonyms: oksi, okézsoké,  oksibuksi

text: first-person singular of neki: to/for me
examples: Semmit se mondott nekem. ― She didn’t say anything to me.
Megvennéd ezt a könyvet nekem? ― Would you buy this book for me?
Virágot hozott nekem. ― He brought me flowers.
nincs testvérem. ― I don’t have siblings.  there is no my-sibling.”)

defs.etymology: Apocopic form of felé (archaic; unrelated to present-day felé (“towards”)), a lexicalization of the fel form of föl (“upper part, surface”) +‎ -é (locative suffix), shortening, then dropping the final vowel.

text: up, upward, upwards (to a physically higher or more elevated position)
examples: Synonym: felfelé
Antonyms: le, lefelé
Coordinate terms: fent, fenn,  felül

text: (archaic) Alternative form of föl (“upper part, surface”)
(rare, dialectal) Alternative form of föl (“skim”, of the milk) or föl (“cream”, the best part)
examples: Synonyms:  felső rész,  felület
Synonyms: felső, feljebbi, fentebbi, fentebb/feljebb/magasabban lévő

defs.etymology: tud +‎ -od

text: second-person singular indicative present definite of tud
examples: Tudod,  ki hívott? ― Do you know who called?
Tudod,  nem mindenki szereti a bort. ― Not everybody likes wine, you know.

defs.etymology: Lexicalization of the o variant of the demonstrative pronoun a(z) + -tt (locative suffix).

text: (demonstrative) there, over there (on a place at some distance from the speaker)
examples: Ott leszek. ― I will be there.
Coordinate term: itt

defs.etymology: The le- stem of van (“to be”) +‎ -het (potential suffix added to verbs), compare lesz, lenni.

text: potential form of van, may/might be
potential form of lesz, may/might become
examples: Este 8-kor már otthon lehet. ― S/he may be already at home at 8 p.m.
Akár miniszterelnök is lehet belőle! ― S/he might even become Prime Minister!

defs.etymology: vala- +‎ mi

examples: Coordinate term:  valaki

text: (informal) around, some, approximately ( before an estimated number)
(informal) quite, rather, truly, indeed (as an intensifier before positive or negative adjectives, also used after the negative nem)
examples: Valami harmincan lehettek. ― There could have been around thirty of them.
Ez valami rettenetes! ― This is quite horrible!
Nem valami jó ez a film. ― This movie is not very good.

text: sometime, later (at an indefinite point of time in the future)
(stressed) almost, nearly (as a shortened version of majdnem, majd is often written in this sense with a final apostrophe, although it is not officially endorsed)
examples: Synonyms: valamikor, egyszer
Ha majd lesz időd, olvasd el ezt a könyvet! ― When you have time later, then read this book.
Synonyms: utána, aztán, azután
Elmentek ebédelni, majd hazamentek. ― They went to have lunch and then they went home.
Synonyms: majdnem, csaknem, szinte, kis híján, jóformán, közel
Majd’ leszakad a vállam, olyan nehéz ez a táska! ― My shoulders are almost getting torn off, this bag is so heavy!

defs.etymology: Lexicalization of mind (“always”, obsolete sense) +‎ -ig (terminative case suffix).
Shortened from találom (“I think, I believe”), the first-person present tense form of the verb talál (“to find”).

examples: Synonyms: esetleg, tán

defs.etymology: Lexicalization of mag (“body”) +‎ -a (possessive suffix). This original meaning of the root word cannot be found in Hungarian, but it is attested in related languages.

examples: Péter lelőtte magát. ― Peter has shot himself.

defs.etymology: köszön (“to thank”) +‎ -öm (personal suffix)

text: first-person singular indicative present definite of köszön
thank you (an expression of gratitude, on the speaker's behalf)
keep the change (if said with some emphasis when handing over a banknote with a value not considerably larger than the required sum)
examples: Coordinate terms: szívesen, nincs mit, szóra sem érdemes, kérem
Köszönöm a segítségét. ― Thank you for your help.
Synonyms: a többi a magáé, az apró a magáé

defs.etymology: sem +‎ mi
From Proto-Uralic *kutte (“ridge”).
Lexicalization of há (an older variant of ha (“if”)) +‎ -t (locative suffix).

text: of course, surely (reacting to a statement to suggest confidence in the truth of it)
examples: Synonyms: nos, szóval
Hát, ez van. ― Well, that's it.
Synonym: hanem
Nem ott van. - Hát? ― It's not there. - Then where?
Ez nem jó. - Hát a másik? ― This isn't good. - And the other one? / What about the other one?
Synonyms: persze; még jó, hogy
Nincs itt? - Nincs hát! ― Isn't it here? - Of course it isn't!

defs.etymology: az +‎ ki
az +‎ mikor

examples: Amikor kértem, hogy ne dohányozzon, azonnal abbahagyta. ― When I asked him not to smoke, he stopped immediately.

defs.etymology: From Proto-Uralic *ku.

examples: Synonym: merre?

Hol vagyon, aki merész ajakát hadi dalnak eresztvén, / A riadó vak mélységet fölverje szavával,  […] Where is the one who, with lips all bold, could thunder a war-song / rousing the gloom of the deep and unsighty abysses,  […]
Where is the one who, with lips all bold, could thunder a war-song / rousing the gloom of the deep and unsighty abysses,  […]

text: now… now, sometimes… sometimes, either… or
examples: Hol itt, hol ott bukkant ki egy delfin a vízből. ― Sometimes here, sometimes there, a dolphin would pop out of the water.
Mindig van valami: hol áramszünet, hol csőtörés. ― There’s always something: either it’s a blackout or a burst pipe.
Hol volt, hol nem volt, volt egyszer egy király. ― Once upon a time there was a king.

defs.etymology: Lexicalization of the otherwise unattested Proto-Hungarian *nek (“to/across/toward something”) +‎ -i (third-person possessive suffix).

examples: Synonyms: számára, részére,  javára
Ezt a könyvet neki vettem. ― I bought this book for her.
Semmit se mondott neki. ― She did not say anything to him.
Virágot hozott neki. ― He brought her flowers.
nincs testvére. ― S/he doesn’t have any siblings.  there is no his/her-sibling.”)

defs.etymology: szó (“word”) +‎ -val (“with”)

text: that is, that is to say, in other words
examples: Synonyms: vagyis, azaz, tehát, röviden, egyszóval, más szóval

text: so, well (used after a pause for thought to introduce a new topic, question or story, or a new thought or question in continuation of an existing topic)
examples: Synonyms: nos, no, na, hát

text: second-person singular of neki: to/for you
examples: Semmit se mondott neked. ― She did not say anything to you.
Ezt neked hoztam. ― I brought this for you.
Virágot hozott neked. ― He brought you flowers.
van testvéred? ― Do you have any siblings?  is there a your-sibling?”)
Coordinate terms: amely, amelyik

defs.etymology: From a Turkic language, compare to Turkish küçük and Turkmen kiçi.

examples: Synonyms: kicsi, -ka, -ke, -cska, -cske, -ikó

defs.etymology: An onomatopoeia.

text: hey (grabbing the attention of someone, possibly with the intent of warning)
examples:
Dózsa György unokája vagyok én, ¶ Népért síró, bús, bocskoros nemes. ¶ Hé, nagyurak, jó lesz tán szóbaállni ¶ Kaszás népemmel, mert a Nyár heves.
I, the grandson of György Dózsa, ¶ a sad peasant-noble, must cry out for my people’s lot. ¶ Ah, you masters, great landlords, perhaps you would speak ¶ to my scythe-bearing people—for the summer is hot.

I, the grandson of György Dózsa, ¶ a sad peasant-noble, must cry out for my people’s lot. ¶ Ah, you masters, great landlords, perhaps you would speak ¶ to my scythe-bearing people—for the summer is hot.

defs.etymology: From Hebrew הא‎.
tény +‎ -leg

examples: Synonym: valóban

defs.etymology: hisz +‎ -em

text: first-person singular indicative present definite of hisz
examples: Nem hiszem, hogy elérjük a buszt. ― I don't think we will catch the bus.
Hiszem, ha látom! ― I'll believe it when I see it.

text: (usually with the case suffix -ban/-ben) belief, impression, anticipation
examples: Abban a hiszemben mentek el nyaralni, hogy a házukban a riasztóberendezés be volt kapcsolva.They left for their summer vacation under the impression that the alarm was set in their house.
They left for their summer vacation under the impression that the alarm was set in their house.
Synonym: elegendő
Nincs sok vizünk, de egy napra biztosan elég. ― We don't have much water but it's certainly enough for a day.
Synonyms: eléggé, viszonylag, aránylag, meglehetősen
Azok nagyon jók, de elég drágák. ― They are very good, but rather expensive.

text: Used in expressions with inflectional suffixes.
examples: elege van ― to be fed up
eleget tesz ― to satisfy, to fulfill, to comply with

defs.etymology: el- +‎ ég
valami +‎ -t

examples: Elfelejtettél valamit? ― Did you forget something?

defs.etymology: From Proto-Ugric *puŋɜ- (“to grasp, to catch”). Cognates include Mansi пуви (puvi).

text: (transitive) to hold (to keep in one's hands)
(transitive) to take (to get into one's hands)
(transitive) to catch, to capture (to seize by force, especially to grab or trap an animal)
(transitive, broadcasting) to receive (to detect a signal from a transmitter)
(transitive, by extension, slang) to listen to, to hear, to understand (to pay attention to someone)
(transitive, intransitive followed by rajta) to affect, to harm (to have an effect on, especially detrimentally)
(intransitive) to write (of a pen or other writing instrument, to leave a mark)
(intransitive)  to transfer (of ink or dye, to leave a stain upon contact)
(transitive, ball games) to mark (to follow a player not in possession of the ball when defending)
(auxiliary, with an infinitive, only in indicative present) will, going to (used to form the future tense)
(reflexive, followed by és) to up and (to do something abruptly or unexpectedly)
examples: Valaki ült is mellette, fogta a kezét, de az arcát valahogy nem látta.Somebody was sitting next to her, held her hand, but somehow she couldn't see his face.
Somebody was sitting next to her, held her hand, but somehow she couldn't see his face.
Itt van, fogd ezt a levelet; és aztán olvasd el, mikor egyedül leszesz.Here, take this letter; read it when you're alone.
Here, take this letter; read it when you're alone.
Mikor eljött az ebédidő, medve koma úgy látta, hogy elég halat fogott, s elhatározta, hogy hazamegy.When lunchtime came, uncle bear found that he had caught enough fish and decided to go home.
When lunchtime came, uncle bear found that he had caught enough fish and decided to go home.
Egyébként egészen jól lehetett fogni az adást.As a matter of fact, I received the broadcast quite clearly.
As a matter of fact, I received the broadcast quite clearly.
Fogod, amit mondok? Észnél vagy?Do you hear what I'm sayin'? Are you out of your mind?
Do you hear what I'm sayin'? Are you out of your mind?
Valaki azt is mondta, hogy le akarták lőni, de nem fogja a golyó.Someone even said that they had wanted to shoot it, but bullets wouldn't harm it.
Someone even said that they had wanted to shoot it, but bullets wouldn't harm it.
Olyan furcsa volt, ahogyan felírta a rendelést: nem fogott a tolla, és elkezdte rázni.It was strange, the way she took the order: her pen wouldn't write, and she started shaking it.
It was strange, the way she took the order: her pen wouldn't write, and she started shaking it.

A rossz festékekkel megfestett újabb szőnyegeken a kék színek fognak, mosás közben kék színt eresztenek [...]In newer carpets dyed with poor dyes, the blue colors transfer, they bleed blue color when being washed [...]
In newer carpets dyed with poor dyes, the blue colors transfer, they bleed blue color when being washed [...]
Csikós I nem fogta a balösszekötőt, az kiugrott és gólt lőtt.Csikós I didn't mark the inside left, who sprang forward and scored a goal.
Csikós I didn't mark the inside left, who sprang forward and scored a goal.
Most azonban jó lesz sietve hazamenni, mert mindjárt esni fog.But now we'd better go home quickly, because it's going to rain soon.
But now we'd better go home quickly, because it's going to rain soon.
Fogta magát és szó nélkül berohant a szobájába.He just up and ran off into his room without a word.
He just up and ran off into his room without a word.

defs.etymology: From Proto-Uralic *piŋe (“tooth”). Cognates include Mansi пуӈк (puňk), Finnish pii.

text: tooth (a sharp projection on a saw or similar implement)
examples: Ez a fog lyukas. ― This tooth has a cavity.
Egy átlagos hegyikerékpár hátsó fogaskerekein rendre 11, 13, 15, 18, 21, 24, 34 fog van.There are 11, 13, 15, 18, 21, 24 and 34 teeth on a standard mountain bike's rear sprockets.
There are 11, 13, 15, 18, 21, 24 and 34 teeth on a standard mountain bike's rear sprockets.
A fűrész egyik foga hiányzik. ― One of the saw’s teeth is missing.

defs.etymology: From the shared stem of van (“to be”) and lesz (“to become; will be”) +‎ -ne.

text: third-person singular conditional present of van
third-person singular conditional present of lesz
examples: Synonym: volna
Egy kis segítségre lenne szükségem. ― I would need a little help.

defs.etymology: From Proto-Uralic *oma (“old, previous”). Cognate with Finnish ammoin (“very long ago”), Estonian ammu (“once upon a time, long ago”), Northern Sami oames (“past, old”), and Erzya умок (umok, “a long time ago”). Compare agg (“aged”), avas (“rancid”), avul (“to become obsolete”), avítt (“antiquated”).

text: (archaic, except in compounds) old, ancient, antique
examples: Synonyms: antik, ódon, régi, ősi
Antonyms: mai, új
Coordinate terms:  ős, közép, új

defs.etymology: An onomatopoeia.

examples: Synonyms: óh, jaj, ja, juj, hű
Ó, értem már! ― Oh, I understand now!

defs.etymology: See óv.

text: (archaic) Alternative form of óv (“to protect, to guard”).
The twenty-fifth letter of the Hungarian alphabet, called ó and written in the Latin script.

defs.etymology: [middle of 13th century] Native word, probably a derivation. Its base word is presumably jóg (“right hand”), an older variant of jog (“law”). Its ending is the obsolete noun-forming suffix -z. For the ending, compare száraz. For the word-initial shift from jo- to i-, compare inkább (“rather”) (older variant jonkább) and irgalom (“mercy”) (jorgat (“to have mercy”) found in Halotti beszéd és könyörgés (“Funeral Sermon and Prayer”)). The notion of right hand and true, honest are connected in other languages, as well, such as German recht, English right, French droit, Finnish oikea.

examples: Synonyms: helytálló, valós
Antonyms: hamis, hazug
Synonyms: derék, becsületes, tisztességes, jóravaló, erényes, erkölcsös

defs.etymology: Shortened from reá.

examples: Ne szórd rá a homokot! ― Don’t throw sand on her!
Gondolsz néha rá? ― Do you ever think of him?
Senki sem emlékszik rá. ― No one remembers her.

text: Synonym of később, later (after -ra/-re for the amount of time passed; usually of days or longer periods)
examples: Húsz évre rá  ― Twenty years later

defs.etymology: Lexicalization of the otherwise unattested Proto-Hungarian *βel (“with”) +‎ -e (possessive suffix).

examples: Menj vele. ― Go with him/her.

defs.etymology: From the pronoun mely (“which”), patterned after the pronouns ilyen (“this kind of”), olyan (“that kind of”). Its form may have been influenced also by the interrogative pronoun mi (“what”). Its original form was probably melyen, this is perhaps mely (interrogative pronoun) + -n (pronoun suffix). First attested in 1748.

text: (followed by an adverb or an adjective) to what extent?, how?, how much?
examples: Synonym: miféle
Milyen idő van? ― What is the weather like?
Milyen színű az autód? ― What color is your car?
Milyen ember a főnököd? ― What kind of person is your boss?
Milyen az idő? ― What is the weather like?
Milyen volt a nyaralásotok? ― What was your vacation like?
Synonym: mennyire
Milyen nagy a házatok? ― How big is your house?
Synonyms: de, mennyire
Milyen kár! ― What a pity!
Milyen gyönyörű idő! ― What beautiful weather!

defs.etymology: ily +‎ -en

examples: Ilyen ember nincs is. ― There is no such man.
Coordinate term: olyan

text: something like this, this kind of thing, such a thing
examples: Ilyen kell nekem is. ― This kind of thing is what I need, too.
Coordinate term: olyan
Coordinate term: oda

defs.etymology: From bízik (“to trust”).

examples: Synonym: biztosan
Synonym: biztosan
Biztos úr! ― Officer!

defs.etymology: úr +‎ -am (possessive suffix)

text: first-person singular single-possession possessive of úr:
examples: Elnézést, uram, meg tudná mondani, merre van a postahivatal?Excuse me, sir, could you tell me where the post office is?
Excuse me, sir, could you tell me where the post office is?
Coordinate terms: asszonyom, hölgyem, kisasszony, fiatalember

defs.etymology: ők (“they”) +‎ -et (accusative suffix)

text: accusative of ők (“they”): them (primarily of humans, as the direct object of a verb)

words: (singular): engem(et) (“me”) ― (informal) téged(et), (formal) magát, (official) önt (“you”) ― őt (“him/her”);(plural): minket/bennünket (“us”) ― (infml) titeket/benneteket, (fml) magukat, (off.) önöket (“you all”) ― őket (“them”)

examples: Hol vannak? Nem látom őket. ― Where are they? I don’t see them.

defs.etymology: Lexicalization of a stem of unknown origin, same as the stem of the adverb viszont +‎ -a (lative case suffix).

text: wrong side (the side designed to be worn or placed inward; as, the wrong side of a garment or of a piece of cloth)
examples: Antonym: szín

defs.etymology: Of uncertain origin. Probably related to Mansi яныг (ânyg).

examples: az egyház nagyjai ― the fathers of the church
a múlt nagyjai ― the great people of the past

defs.etymology: tud (“to know; to be able”) +‎ -ja (personal suffix)

text: third-person singular indicative present definite of tud
third-person singular subjunctive present definite of tud
examples: Nem tudja, hogy mit csináljon. ― He doesn't know what to do.
Tudja, hogy mit csinál. ― She knows what she is doing.
Tudja, mit ünnepelnek itt? ― Do you  know what they are celebrating here?

defs.etymology: Probably related to más.

examples: Synonym:  máma

Ma nem mentem iskolába. Azaz mentem, de csak, hogy hazakéredzkedjem az osztályfőnökömtől.I didn’t go to school today. Or rather, I did go, but only to ask my class teacher’s permission to take the day off.
I didn’t go to school today. Or rather, I did go, but only to ask my class teacher’s permission to take the day off.
Coordinate terms: holnap, tegnap

text: (attributively, before any time of day) this …… (morning etc.), to-…… (as in “tonight”)
examples: ma reggel/délelőtt ― this morning
ma délután ― this afternoon
ma este ― this evening
ma éjjel/éjszaka ― tonight
ma hajnalban, délben, éjfélkor ― at dawn, noon, midnight today

defs.etymology: Possibly borrowed from Alanic *ægas (“undiminished, whole”). Compare Ossetian ӕга́с (ægás, “whole”).

text: whole, entire, complete (with all parts included, with nothing missing)
examples: Ezek a gépek a 20. század elejétől az egész világon elterjedtek.From the beginning of the 20th century, these machines have spread across the whole world.
From the beginning of the 20th century, these machines have spread across the whole world.
A százalékos adatok egész számra lettek kerekítve.Percentage data has been rounded to integer numbers.
Percentage data has been rounded to integer numbers.

text: entirely, completely (to the maximum extent or degree)
(with an adverb) all the way, up until (all throughout until reaching a place or a point in time)
(colloquial) quite, rather, fairly (not entirely, but reasonably or sufficiently)
examples: Synonyms: egészen, teljesen
Tudom, hogy sírni fog. Most már egész biztos vagyok benne.I know she's going to cry. I'm now entirely sure of it.
I know she's going to cry. I'm now entirely sure of it.
Synonym: egészen
Egész hazáig néztem kifelé a csillagos éjszakába, de nem a csillagokat láttam.All the way home I was looking out into the starry night, but I didn't see the stars.
All the way home I was looking out into the starry night, but I didn't see the stars.
Ahhoz képest, hogy nincs a helyiségnek ablaka, egész jól aludtam.I have slept quite well, considering that the room has no windows.
I have slept quite well, considering that the room has no windows.
Synonyms: egészen, meglehetősen

text: entirety, whole (something complete, without any parts missing)
(colloquial) the whole thing (the topic of the conversation; the situation or story just mentioned)
(arithmetic) Names the integer part of a decimal fraction, when it is spoken out loud.
examples: Ezután lassan, nagy élvezettel egészben lenyeli zsákmányát.After this, it swallows its prey whole, slowly and with great pleasure.
After this, it swallows its prey whole, slowly and with great pleasure.
Ennyi az egész. ― That's all.
Mindebből egy szó sem igaz, csak kitaláltad az egészet.Not a word of this is true, you just made the whole thing up.
Not a word of this is true, you just made the whole thing up.
A matematikailag pontos érték nem kettő, hanem egy egész hét tized [...]The exact mathematical value is not two, but one point seven [...]
The exact mathematical value is not two, but one point seven [...]

defs.etymology: sajnál +‎ -om

text: first-person singular indicative present definite of sajnál
examples: Sajnálom, hogy nem tudtunk találkozni. ― I'm sorry we could not meet.

defs.etymology: no (interjection) +‎ s (“and”, conjunction)
mi +‎ -kor

examples: Mikor indulsz? ― When are you leaving?

defs.etymology: vagy (second-person singular indicative present indefinite of van) +‎ -unk (personal suffix)

text: first-person plural indicative present indefinite of van
examples: Jól vagyunk. ― We are doing fine.
